title: WTM seeks to impact United Nations climate change event
text:
WTM seeks to impact United Nations climate change event 3 July 2015 | By Edward Robertson Save 
World Travel Market will be pre-empting the global green movement when it holds this year’s World Responsible Tourism Day (WRTD). 
The trade show will be using the day to tackle the issue of climate change with speakers focusing on the problem and the role that tourism can play in helping find solutions. 
In doing so, the event, which is held on November 4, will come long before the United Nations Climate Change Conference, which takes place from November 30 to December 11 in Paris. Organisers hope some of the WRTD event will help inform debate at the UN conference. 
The French event is hoping to succeed where the previous event held in 2009 in Copenhagen failed, by reaching a global consensus on how best to reduce greenhouse gas emissions so that the global temperature increase is limited to two degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels. 
WRTD will start with a keynote address from Kevin Anderson, professor of energy and climate change in the school of mechanical, aerospace and civil engineering at the University of Manchester. 
He is also the deputy director of the Tyndall Centre for Climate Change Research and advises the Prime Minister’s office on carbon trading. 
Following his keynote address there will be a panel debate, chaired by BBC journalist Stephen Sackur, which will see the pair joined by senior travel industry executives to discuss how the travel industry can help in the reduction of greenhouse gasses. 
The afternoon’s content concludes with the carbon debate, which will see the motion “The tourism industry could do much more to take responsibility for reducing carbon emissions” contested. 
WTM senior director Simon Press said: “The United Nations Climate Change Conference in Paris has the potential to have a significant impact on the travel industry. 
“With WTM taking place weeks before the conference we can help set the agenda by discussing climate change and the role the travel industry can play. Anderson is a highly-respected speaker and will present a thought-provoking, controversial and potentially worrying picture of where the world is on tackling climate change.”
